results.title: Child guidance clinic [Abridged version]
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Allen Stark and Don Haldane
results.brief_description: Narrator Neil Leroy drops in at the Child Adjustment Services center for the study and treatment of the emotionally disturbed child set up by the Toronto Board of Education. Here, psychologists, social workers and psychiatrists, with the cooperation of parents and teachers, are learning how to deal with children’s emotional problems and to help them develop into healthy, happy adults. Through the story of young Nick, we see how early diagnosis and treatment of a child’s maladjustment can change him into a normal, outgoing youngster.

results.title: Child draw nearer
results.creator_credit: Bristol Films, Annie Mygind and Martin Shuttleworth
results.brief_description: This film shows the advances made at a special school for teaching autistic children and how they began to respond to patience and to use language in a normal way. Commentary by Norman Tyrrell and Val Bryan.

results.title: Child development: infants are individuals
results.creator_credit: Clinic of Child Development and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: The material in this film is taken from the Clinic’s photographic records made over a period of 20 years. Each child’s unique individuality asserts itself even in infancy. Bob, Amy, Bess, and Dan at the age of five, we look at their progress from about 12 weeks old to five years.

results.title: Child care: the management challenge for the 1990's
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Susan Lambert and Mark Gould
results.brief_description: Twenty percent of all women workers have children under five and in 56% of families with dependent children, both parents work. Inadequate childcare facilities for these working parents can result in high absenteeism, low productivity and a high turnover rate. More and more companies are seeing the advantages to providing a carefully planned work-based childcare centre which ultimately benefits not just the employees, but the employer and the children. This video provides several examples of Sydney-based companies who have taken the initiative, including the Vacation Program run jointly by the NAB, ANZ, NML and CML, the Messengers Cottage Creche for the Esso/Lend Lease employees and the Flemington Market’s proposed childcare centre. The consensus appears to be a higher retention of skilled workers, particularly women, and an overall improvement in productivity.

results.title: Child care means business
results.creator_credit: Commonwealth Department of Human Services and Health, Louise Leitch and Elena Guest
results.brief_description: A panel of employers debate employer sponsored child care, examining economic arguments together with philosophical and practical issues. Andrew Olle hosts a panel including small, medium and big business along with leading work and family strategists.

creators_primary.name: Commonwealth Department of Human Services and Health

results.title: Child behaviour = you
results.brief_description: Would you pick up a baby when he cries for attention, or let him yell out his little lungs? This cartoon film for parents poses many such questions that confront a mother during the course of her day. Made with the counsel of child specialists, it provides a perceptive guide to understanding what motivates both good and problem behavior in children from infancy to adolescence, and how to draw out the best.

results.title: Child abuse: the people next door
results.creator_credit: Shire Films, Dan Bessie and Helen Garvey
results.brief_description: This film helps parents recognise the potential for child abuse within themselves and others, the kinds of situations that can make that potential a reality, and how and where to find help.

results.title: Child abuse: emergency management
results.creator_credit: Producers Service Center, S William Hinzman and Paul McCollough
results.brief_description: A child is brought to an hospital emergency room with bruises that indicate possible abuse. This program addresses how to identify whether a crime has been committed, procedures emergency room personnel should follow upon admission of a child and how to approach the parents. The main characters are portrayed by experienced hospital staff and the program emphasises that help can be provided only if the interaction with the parents is handled with skill, support and empathy. Highlights the importance of an interdisciplinary approach to assist the family and child.

results.title: Child abuse: cradle of violence
results.creator_credit: Bananza Films, Jerry Kingsley, J. Gary Mitchell and Richard Gebhardt
results.brief_description: Through penetrating on-camera interviews with parents, many of them former abusers, the film introduces the grim reality of child abuse. Shows hopeful models for dealing with abuse problems. Also looks at positive parenting, and underlines the need for citizen reporting of suspected abuse so that the abusive family can be helped.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bananza Films, Jerry Kingsley, J. Gary Mitchell and Richard Gebhardt

results.title: Child's toy tin magic lantern with candle projection
results.credit_line: The Empire Magic Lantern Outfit, Germany, c. 1900 ACMI Collection. Donated by William Kerr on behalf of Edwin Schefferle.
results.brief_description:
Early magic lantern projections depicted cautionary religious and supernatural scenes, like sinners roasting in Purgatory and Death wielding a scythe. Luckily, magic lanterns weren’t used only by clergymen but also by a wide variety of entertainers and educators in homes, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations, scientists revealed the latest discoveries and charlatan magicians spooked audiences with dancing skeletons.

Magic lanterns were made in all shapes and sizes from materials as diverse as biscuit tins and brass to mahogany and nickel. They were even mass-produced as children’s toys in the 19th century.
